items.title: Japanese researchers train AI to 'mumble' to itself

featured_image.name: Researchers find algorithm for large-scale brain simulations

items.description:
New research from Japan suggests artificial intelligence systems may benefit from a surprisingly human trait: talking to themselves. Scientists at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) have demonstrated that AI models learn more efficiently, adapt to new situations more easily, and handle multiple tasks better when trained to use internal "mumbling" alongside short-term memory systems.

The findings, published in Neural Computation on January 28, reveal that combining self-directed inner speech with working memory architecture allows AI to generalize across different tasks more effectively while requiring far less training data than conventional approaches.[1][2]

items.title: South Korea's Kospi breaks 5,100 for first time as gold tops $5,200

featured_image.name: KOSPI tops 5,100 for the first time on record, KOSDAQ ...

items.description:
Asian markets delivered a mixed performance on Wednesday as investors navigated a complex landscape of record-breaking U.S. equities, soaring precious metals, and a weakening dollar, all while awaiting the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later in the day.

South Korea's Kospi broke through the 5,100 level for the first time in history, rising more than 1.5% in early trading. Meanwhile, Japan's Nikkei 225 fell about 0.5% as a strengthening yen weighed on export-heavy stocks. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index pointed to gains, with futures trading above the previous close.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Gold hits record high as dollar falls to four-year low

featured_image.name: Trump triggers flight from US dollar

items.description:
The U.S. dollar tumbled to its lowest level since early 2022 on Tuesday after President Donald Trump appeared unconcerned about its recent slide, describing the currency as "doing great" when asked if it had fallen too much. The remarks accelerated a sell-off that lifted gold to record highs above $5,200 an ounce on Wednesday.

The dollar index, which measures the greenback against six major currencies, dropped to 95.566 on Tuesday — its weakest reading in nearly four years — before stabilizing around 96 in Asian trading on Wednesday. Trump's comments in Iowa intensified what had already been the currency's largest three-day drop since last April's tariff turmoil.[1][2][3]

items.title: Stone tools found in China push back date of composite technology in East Asia

featured_image.name: Oldest hafted stone tools in East Asia discovered in China ...

items.description:
Archaeologists working at the Xigou site in central China have unearthed more than 2,600 stone artifacts that represent the earliest known composite tools in East Asia, challenging the long-held assumption that early humans in the region lagged behind their African and European counterparts in technological innovation.

The findings, published this week in Nature Communications, document sophisticated toolmaking techniques spanning roughly 90,000 years at the site in Henan Province's Danjiangkou Reservoir Region.[1][2][3]

items.title: China approves first Nvidia H200 AI chip imports amid Huang visit

featured_image.name: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang in Shanghai amid China regulatory ...

items.description:
China has granted approval for its first shipment of Nvidia H200 artificial intelligence chips, marking a pivotal shift in Beijing's approach to balancing its AI ambitions with efforts to promote domestic semiconductor development. The authorization covers several hundred thousand units and was issued during Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's ongoing visit to the country, according to Reuters.[1]

The approval, which extends to three major Chinese internet companies, signals a thaw in tensions that saw Chinese customs briefly block H200 shipments earlier this month despite U.S. export clearance. Sources indicate that Alibaba, Tencent, and ByteDance are among the firms granted initial clearance, with additional companies awaiting future approvals.[2][1]

items.title: AI could propose and test scientific hypotheses within five years, researchers say

featured_image.name: AI-led robotic lab develops enzyme to withstand higher ...

items.description:
Artificial intelligence could be autonomously generating scientific hypotheses and conducting research experiments within the next five years, according to leading researchers, even as philosophers and scientists debate whether machines can ever truly replace human researchers.

EPFL associate professor Robert West and Northwestern University professor Ágnes Horvát said in an interview published this week that the role of AI in science is poised for a fundamental shift—from assisting with writing and data analysis to actually proposing the questions that drive research.[1][2]

"I think the next step, and perhaps five years is a reasonable time frame for that, is for AI to come up with the ideas we study," Horvát said. "That's very different territory because then the AI is providing the hypothesis that needs to be researched."[1]

items.title: Liverpool scientists find 3D material that mimics graphene

featured_image.name: 3D Material mimics graphene's electronic speed without the ...

items.description:
Scientists at the University of Liverpool have discovered a three-dimensional material that replicates graphene's remarkable electron-conducting properties while overcoming the fragility that has limited the wonder material's practical applications.

The research, published Tuesday in the journal Matter, identifies that a compound called hafnium stannide (HfSn₂) can mimic graphene's fast, two-dimensional electron flow despite having a fully three-dimensional atomic structure. The discovery opens new pathways for developing more robust materials for low-energy computing technologies.[1][2][3]

items.title: Kim Jong Un teases nuclear plans ahead of Workers' Party congress

featured_image.name: Xi Jinping Holds Talks With Kim Jong Un In Beijing

items.description:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un declared that the upcoming Workers' Party congress will reveal "next-stage plans" for strengthening the country's nuclear war deterrent, the state-run Korean Central News Agency reported on Wednesday. The announcement came after Kim supervised a ballistic missile test on Tuesday that drew international condemnation.

Kim made the remarks while overseeing a test of a large-caliber multiple-rocket launch system that KCNA said demonstrated "significant upgrades" in strike power, mobility, and accuracy. The rockets reportedly struck targets 358 kilometers away in the East Sea. Kim emphasized that developing a "reliable offensive capability and deterrence strategy" is a key policy of the ruling Workers' Party to counter any attempts at armed conflict.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Rubio warns of military force as Venezuela resists US demands

featured_image.name: Trump Is Ready to Use Force to Ensure Venezuela Cooperates ...

items.description:
Secretary of State Marco Rubio warned Tuesday that the Trump administration is prepared to use military force to ensure Venezuela's acting President Delcy Rodríguez complies with American demands, escalating tensions nearly a month after US special forces captured Nicolás Maduro in a dramatic predawn raid on Caracas.[1][2]

The warning came as Colombia's President Gustavo Petro called for Maduro to be returned to Venezuela to face trial in his home country rather than in the United States. "They have to return him and have him tried by a Venezuelan court, not a US one," Petro said Tuesday, one week before a scheduled February 3 meeting with Trump at the White House.[3][4][5]

items.title: SoftBank in talks to invest $30B more in OpenAI, WSJ reports

featured_image.name: SoftBank in Talks to Invest $30 Billion More in OpenAI, WSJ ...

items.description:
SoftBank Group Corp. is in discussions to invest up to an additional $30 billion in OpenAI, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday, a move that would deepen the Japanese conglomerate's position as one of the artificial intelligence startup's largest financial backers.[1][2]

The potential investment comes as OpenAI pursues a massive $100 billion funding round that could value the ChatGPT maker at up to $830 billion, one of the largest private fundraises in history. The negotiations are part of CEO Sam Altman's globe-spanning effort to secure capital from deep-pocketed investors, including Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds.[3][4][5][6]

items.title: Holocaust survivors urge action against rising hatred on 81st anniversary of Auschwitz liberation

featured_image.name: Holocaust survivors mark 81st anniversary of Auschwitz ...

items.description: Holocaust survivors, world leaders, and ordinary citizens gathered at ceremonies across Europe and beyond on Tuesday to commemorate International Holocaust Remembrance Day, marking 81 years since the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau. With the community of survivors dwindling and concerns about antisemitism rising, speakers at events from Poland to London urged the world to remember — and to act.

items.title: Ancient tools found in Greece and China rewrite early human history

featured_image.name: Scientists Find 430,000-Year-Old Wooden Tools in Greece

items.description:
Researchers have uncovered 430,000-year-old wooden implements in Greece and 160,000-year-old composite stone tools in China, a pair of discoveries that are reshaping scientists' understanding of early human technological capabilities.

The Greek wooden tools, described in a study published Monday in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, are the oldest known handheld wooden implements ever found, pushing back evidence of this type of tool use by at least 40,000 years. Meanwhile, hafted stone tools found at a site in central China represent the earliest confirmed composite tools in East Asia, according to research published Tuesday in Nature Communications.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Ukraine-Russia war casualties near 2 million, CSIS study finds

featured_image.name: Troop Casualties in Ukraine War Near 2 Million, Study Finds

items.description:
Nearly four years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the combined military toll of the conflict is approaching two million casualties, according to a study released Tuesday by the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

The Washington-based think tank estimates approximately 1.2 million Russian troops and close to 600,000 Ukrainian soldiers have been killed, wounded, or gone missing since February 2022, bringing the current total to roughly 1.8 million. By this spring, the study projects, that figure will reach two million if current trends continue.[1][2]

items.title: Colombia's Petro says Maduro should face trial in Venezuela

featured_image.name: Petro Says Maduro Should be Returned to Face Trial in ...

items.description:
Colombian President Gustavo Petro said Tuesday that ousted Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro should be returned to face trial in his home country rather than in the United States, adding a new layer of complexity to regional tensions one week before his scheduled meeting with President Donald Trump.

"They have to return him and have him tried by a Venezuelan court, not a US one," Petro said Tuesday, according to Bloomberg. The statement marks the Colombian leader's most direct intervention yet in the diplomatic standoff over Maduro's fate since US forces captured the former Venezuelan president in a dramatic pre-dawn raid on January 3.[1]

items.title: NASA's Juno measures Europa's ice shell at 18 miles thick

featured_image.name: NASA's Juno probe will peer beneath the icy crust of Europa ...

items.description:
Jupiter's moon Europa remains one of the most tantalizing targets in the search for extraterrestrial life, but two recent studies paint a complex and sometimes contradictory picture of whether its vast subsurface ocean could actually support living organisms.

NASA announced on Sunday that data from the Juno spacecraft has provided the first direct measurement of Europa's ice shell thickness, determining it averages about 18 miles (29 kilometers) in the region observed during a 2022 flyby. The findings, published in Nature Astronomy in December, represent a landmark measurement that settles a long-standing scientific debate over whether the shell is thin or thick.[1][2][3]

"The 18-mile estimate relates to the cold, rigid, conductive outer-layer of a pure water ice shell," said Steve Levin, Juno project scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. "If an inner, slightly warmer convective layer also exists, which is possible, the total ice shell thickness would be even greater."[2][3]

items.title: Tesla brand value drops 36% as Musk's politics erode trust

featured_image.name: Tesla investor survey shows 85% believe Musk's politics are ...

items.description:
Tesla faces a crossroads this week as its brand value hits a three-year low and Wall Street braces for another year of declining profitability. The electric vehicle maker is scheduled to report fourth-quarter 2025 earnings on Wednesday, January 28, amid mounting evidence that CEO Elon Musk's political activities and the company's aging vehicle lineup are weighing heavily on business performance.

According to Brand Finance, Tesla's brand value fell by $15.4 billion, or 36%, in 2025, marking its third consecutive annual decline. The London-based research firm now values the Tesla brand at $27.61 billion, down from $43 billion at the start of 2025 and well below its peak of $66.2 billion in January 2023.[1][2][3]

items.title: Study finds narrow ocean bands absorb 72% of seas' carbon

featured_image.name: Ocean fronts revealed as key players in Earth's carbon cycle

items.description:
Narrow bands of ocean covering just over one-third of the world's seas are responsible for absorbing nearly three-quarters of the carbon dioxide that oceans pull from the atmosphere, according to new research that reshapes scientific understanding of Earth's carbon cycle.

The study, published in Nature Climate Change, reveals that ocean fronts—turbulent boundaries where different water masses collide—cover 36 percent of the global ocean but account for 72 percent of total oceanic carbon dioxide uptake, absorbing approximately 1.8 billion tons of carbon annually.[1][2][3]

"This is the first time we've been able to quantify the disproportionate role that ocean fronts play in absorbing atmospheric CO2 on a global scale, and it has major implications for climate modelling," said lead author Dr. Kai Yang, who completed the research during his PhD at the University of Tasmania's Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies (IMAS) and is now a postdoctoral researcher at Xiamen University in China.[4][1]

items.title: OpenAI releases free AI workspace for scientists

featured_image.name: Introducing Prism | OpenAI

items.description:
OpenAI released Prism on Tuesday, a free AI-powered research and writing workspace designed to accelerate scientific work. The platform integrates GPT-5.2 and is available to anyone with a ChatGPT account, marking the company's first dedicated tool for the scientific community.[1][2][3]

"In 2025, AI changed software development forever," OpenAI said in its announcement. "In 2026, we expect a comparable shift in science."[4]

items.title: Lunai Bioworks launches AI tool to block chemical weapon design

featured_image.name: Without safeguards, AI-Biology integration risks accelerating future ...

items.description:
Lunai Bioworks on Tuesday announced the deployment of Sentinel, a transformer-based AI safeguard designed to prevent large language models and scientific AI systems from generating novel chemical agents. The Sacramento-based biotech company said the technology embeds directly within foundation models to screen molecular outputs in real time, functioning as what CEO David Weinstein described as "the immune system for scientific AI."[1][2]

"As AI models become more powerful, safety has to move closer to the core," Weinstein said in a statement. "Sentinel operates inside AI systems—not outside them—stopping dangerous chemical designs before they are ever produced."[3][1]

The launch comes amid mounting concern over the dual-use risks of advanced AI in chemistry and biology, with major AI companies including Anthropic and OpenAI warning that powerful models could assist bad actors in developing biological and chemical threats.

items.title: OpenAI launches dedicated team to accelerate AI use in science

featured_image.name: Altman touts trillion-dollar AI vision as OpenAI ...

items.description:
OpenAI has unveiled a dedicated team to transform the use of artificial intelligence in scientific research, positioning its GPT-5 model as a collaborative partner for mathematicians and scientists while urging policymakers to expand support for AI-driven discovery.

The initiative, called OpenAI for Science, was first announced in October 2025 and is led by Kevin Weil, a company vice president with a background in particle physics who nearly completed a PhD at Stanford before entering the tech industry.[1][2]
